awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Interplay of metal coordination and ligand-based reactivity in complexes of oligopyrrolic fragments
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemical Synthesis program is supporting fundamental research of Professor Elisa Tomat at the University of Arizona. Professor Tomat will employ selected oligopyrrolic compounds to investigate the interplay of metal coordination and ligand-based redox chemistry in transition metal complexes. This work focuses on the synthesis and ligand properties of oligopyrroles.  These new substances are inspired by naturally occurring compounds derived from bacterial biosynthesis and from the oxidative metabolism of heme. The investigation of ligand systems which act as electron sources or reservoirs offers new avenues for the engineering of reactivity pathways, thereby creating a conceptual framework for the development of versatile tunable catalysts of potentially high impact in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry. Professor Tomat will integrate the research and educational components of this project within Chemistry Discovery, a new outreach program for middle school students. Through a series of workshops aimed at highlighting the connections between everyday experience and chemistry advances, Chemistry Discovery provides middle school students with a discovery-based experience that captures the creativity of the STEM fields through experiments. Professor Tomat has established partnerships with local school districts and charter schools.  Chemistry Discovery reaches an underprivileged community which is underrepresented in the sciences. In addition to the production of novel educational resources, Chemistry Discovery engages undergraduate students in the development of outreach workshops through a one-unit undergraduate course offering. The program promotes the pursuit of higher education in the STEM fields by providing an opportunity for middle-school students to discuss scientific observations while interacting with college students.

In this research, new methods are to  be developed for the synthesis of dipyrrolic and tripyrrolic ligands. Because the electronic structure of oligopyrroles is highly tunable by synthetic manipulations, a range of coordination and redox properties will be accessed. This research seeks to  facilitate the design of complexes which enlist both the ligand platform and the metal center as sites of electron exchange. The coordination and redox chemistry of these classes of oligopyrrolic ligands will be investigated, in particular with respect to late transition metals of potential interest for catalytic applications. Trends in redox properties will be correlated with reactivity profiles involving ligand-based one-electron exchanges.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Dr. Tomat and coworkers at the University of Arizona have discovered two new classes of redox-active ligands, i.e., compounds that bind transition metals (e.g., palladium, copper, zinc, platinum) and also engage in redox processes and serve as electron reservoirs. The structural motifs of the investigated compounds were inspired by naturally occurring pigments that derive form the metabolism of red blood cells in human physiology. This work showed that the tripyrrindione and dipyrrindione frameworks are robust platforms for one-electron transformations and that the photophysical and magnetic properties of their complexes can be shifted depending on their redox state. For instance, reversible redox-responsive emission properties were reported in fluorophores for potential applications in functional materials. The chemical characterization of the new complexes also revealed several non-covalent interactions (e.g., hydrogen bonding, aromatic stacking) that pave the way to the construction of highly tunable supramolecular assemblies.  

The project has provided substantial training opportunities for six graduate and three undergraduate students, who were trained on synthetic and purification methods, chemical characterization techniques (including UV-visible absorption, fluorescence, NMR and EPR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and X-ray crystallography), data analysis, as well as oral and written communication of research findings. The PI and all the trainees have presented their work as posters or seminars at a variety of conferences. Four graduate students have received departmental and/or college-level fellowships for research excellence. The Tomat group has also participated in mentoring programs aimed at supporting and retaining students from underrepresented and underserved groups, including students with disabilities, first-generation students, and transfer students from local community colleges (e.g., Arizona Science Engineering and Math Scholars (ASEMS), NSF-funded S-STEM Supporting Success of Science Transfer Students).

The research goals of the project were integrated within a significant educational effort through Chemistry Discovery, a chemistry course and outreach program for middle-school students. Each year, this one-unit elective course engages both graduate and undergraduate students, including several members of the Tomat research group, in the production of a series of 5-6 workshops that highlight the connections between everyday experience and chemistry knowledge. These events are hosted at the Flandrau Science Center and Planetarium, which is the main outreach venue of the UArizona College of Science and provides precious logistical support for the program. The workshops engage middle-school experimentalists (over 100 per year) in a discovery-based experience that captures the creativity of the chemical sciences. To date 86 UArizona students (i.e., 62 undergraduate and 24 graduate students) have participated in the Chemistry Discovery program, which has hosted over 800 visitors from dozens of middle schools in the Tucson metropolitan area and the Tohono O?odham Nation.

Overall, this project has resulted in a body of work detailed in 13 peer-reviewed publications, as well as 2 masters theses and 2 doctoral dissertations. The research findings have advanced the field of coordination chemistry while also providing molecular platforms and insights for future applications in other disciplines, including catalysis, supramolecular chemistry, and materials science. Furthermore, the project has had significant societal impact beyond its scientific goals through the advanced training of the chemical workforce (both at the undergraduate and graduate levels) and the promotion of careers in the chemical sciences through multiple mentoring programs and outreach activities in the community. 

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2022
Modified by: Elisa Tomat
